Get Your Wine Glass Filled to the Brim.The “Joan” is an off-menu inside joke, and the best wine deal in town. By Alex BeggsDecember 23, 2019FacebookTwitterEmailPhoto by Laura MurrayFacebookTwitterEmailThis is Highly Recommend, a column dedicated to our very opinionated editors’ favorite things to eat, drink, and buy.The standard restaurant wine pour is five ounces. It puddles in the bottom of the glass like yesterday’s rainfall. It costs close to as much as the entire bottle retails for. This is a widely accepted truth.But is it enough?Most of the time, sure! But in an amber-glowing Champagne bar in New York City, you can have much, much more.At The Riddler, which has a new location in the West Village (the original is in SF), you can order a “Joan,” off-menu. You can choose bubbles, white, or red. The bottles vary from day to day, but there’s no such thing as bad wine at this place. The waiter will pour the wine into your glass, and pour, and pour, and pour...until the surface tension of the wine vibrates slightly. Any more and it would overflow. Laugh, lean forward, and sip.The Joan is a caricature. An inside joke about a “fun-time suburban mom” from the childhood of owner Jen Pelka’s friend—perhaps you know a version of Joan. She showed up to the kids’ soccer game with a flask of cheap white wine. “We have so many guests who tell us that their aunt is named Joan, and that she drinks her wines Joan-style,” said Pelka.But here the Joan takes the cliché about “mom wine” to a hyperbolic and satirical place, like that Amy Schumer sketch with the gigantic wine glass. (At a restaurant funded solely by female investors, you might see it as another level of the bar’s implicit feminism.) But it’s also a GREAT DEAL. $16 for two and a half glasses of wine!When I stopped in for oysters and a (very good, BTW) burger recently, I had the red Joan, a juicy Chilean pinot noir. (People don’t usually bother to even ask what the wine is, though, it’s more about the spectacle.) The sight of my 100 percent full glass inspired my jealous and thrifty dinner mate to order the Joan bubbles, which were big popping bubbles of cava—the perfect companion to the cheesy burger. “There’s a two-Joan maximum, FYI,” warned the waiter. Joan is more than half a bottle of wine. Makes sense.This is a bar where caviar comes with Lay’s potato chips, where you can have pristine crudo before a burger and fries, and wash it down with obscure expensive Champagne or a pony of High Life. The atmosphere is light-hearted and fun and keeps the whole “Champagne bar” thing from getting too stuffy, which is Pelka’s mission. There’s a ginormous bottle of Krug in the bathroom behind emergency glass. Don’t think too hard about it—order a Joan.Go there: The RiddlerExplore Bon AppétitHighly RecommendWineNew YorkRecipes you want to make. Cooking advice that works.
